Blog.post: I hope this will capture and reflect the latest experience in my career. Right now I have given it a name that define the beginning of my career. I hope one day it will evolve into a broader envelope from the enriching experiences I receive on a daily basis.

When things don't go according to plan, step back and make sure you've cover all the small changes before moving forward. Try to explain the anomaly. Be confident about your judgement. That's how most brilliant people shine, they believe in themselves.

I hate to lose a single idea before life and work hasten me to accomplish more. There is nothing more important than making sure my life experience is securely built into the model/network of my character.
This is my first blog. How exciting!

July 1 Canada Day - Let's Celebrate 12-1pm - Leave Ottawa after lunch 2-3pm - Arrive at Tremblant, check in and settle down 4-6pm - Canada Day events at the village dinner - fondudu? evening - Relax and watch fireworks July 2nd 8-1pm - Dave's going golfing/Irene's going hot-tubbing Lunch - BBQ Burger lunch at home 2-4pm - Sommet des LÃ©gendes at Le Circuit Mont-Tremblant 4-5pm - gondola ride to the top of the summit! ... see if we can see the sun sets dinner - Steak dinner evening entertainments - Movie, card game, ps2, games, etc July 3rd Breakfast 9-12pm - Biking (Destination = Simon's favourite THE ice-cream place) Lunch - short lunch for Dave/ big lunch for ME! 1pm - Dave's going rock climbing/Irene's going canoeing dinner - HK style BBQ evening entertainment - I wanna go clubbing! July 4th Breakfast 10am - pack up and checkout 10:30-1:30pm - lunch and beach (Molson Beachfest) 1:30-3:30pm - Massage and baths 4pm - bye bye Tremblant

This book is superb in describing how most large companies stumble in fostering innovation. I am totally amazed by the amount of research and case studies that goes into this very book. I suppose this is how most profs at the Havard school of business approach the class room. Glad to have picked up this great work. The Innovator's Dilemma by Clayton M. Christensen ISBN 0-06-052199-6

Here is a very good passage from a book I'm reading. Since most of us are engineers it's worth sharing with the rest of you - David. Solving problems is a high-visibility process; preventing problems is low-visibility. This is illustrated by an old parable. In ancient China there was a family of healers, one of whom was known throughout the land and employed as a physician to a great lord. The physician was asked which of his family was the most skillful healer. He replied, "I tend to the sick and dying with drastic and dramatic treatments, and on occasion someone is cured and my name gets out among the lords." "My elder brother cures sickness when it just begins to take root, and his skills are known among the local peasants and neighbors." "My eldest brother is able to sense the spirit of sickness and eradicate it before it takes form. His name is unknown outside our home." Great [engineers/developers] recognize that their [work/code] will be flawed, so instrument their [work/code], and create [design tools/toolchains] designed to sniff out problems before a symptom even exists.

Do you know more Chineses died in WWII than Jews? Do you know there were more than seventeen millions WWII casualties in China? More than 90% of those are civilians slaughtered by the Japanese invaders. The death toll is the second highese below Germany and higher than America. While most country has their WWII memorial day, there is no such date in China because of the political circumstance. Someone is in the process of collecting millions of signature to support the idea of naming September the 18th as the Chinese WWII Memorial Day, please spend a minute to sign up in this website: urlLink http://www.wwgc.cc/qianming/gcqm.asp This is a simplified Chinese website. If you need help, let me know. This website provide storys and links about Nanjing Massacre if you are lack of the background: urlLink http://www.cnd.org/njmassacre/ Let's hope there will be no more war.

Hi, There is a RFC published on April 1, 2003 about setting an evil bit in the IP header. urlLink RFC 3514 This security flag (evil bit) will be set to 1 for the packet with evil intent, or coming from an evil source :-) Hahahaha... cute idea. Lucas

Some of you know I just purchase new tires. After a lot of research, I bought my tires from urlLink www.tiretrends.com . It is Canadian. It takes a week to get your tires but it worth the wait. I save around a hundred buck. You get a big discount right of the bat, shipping is $10x4 and there is no PST!!! Once the tires arrived, bring them to Costco to enjoy another saving $10x4 for installation.

First tip is for ppl who doesn't want to keep checking the blog all the time for posts/comments. This is done in your Dashboard, so you would have to sign in to www.blogger.com To make posts go to your mail box, simply go to Settings->Email and type in your email address. To make comments go to your mail box, simply go to Settings->Comments and type your email address in the appropriate field.

Hey guys and gals, Since the job postings are mostly long and probably not everyone wants to read them, I would suggest all new postings should be posted to this thread as new comments. Hi, Anyone interested in some building tours on Saturday (June 5)? Some buildings that interest me are: Canada Post National Control Centre (reservation required, only a few space left !!) Canada Post Ottawa Mail Processing Plant Ottawa Jail Ottawa Citizen (the printing press room is described as "the size of a football field") Lemieux Island Water Purification Plant (the island along the Parkway) Supreme Court NRC Lab Government House Most buildings open from 10am to 4pm on Saturday. If you plan to go, let me know NOW. Some tours require advance registration. If you have other buildings that interest you, feel free to add to the list. urlLink It should be a fun day! Lucas

All right! Now the ever famous Ottawa Bunch (aka Ottawa Group) is now moving on to bigger and better things. We know have our own web central to express our gratitude, emotions, feelings, philosophies, principles, morals, ethics, pet peeves, and any other unstable and traumatizing emotion that a person may experience. Please do not be alarmed by some of the postings that may appear...we may be crazy but we're not insane...not when we were last checked out anyway... ;-) Special thanks goes out to our technical guru, David, who I'm sure laboured tirelessly through the night to set this up. ;-) We can only imagine the trauma and the sacrifice that he put out in order to create an outlet for this crazy bunch of people. hahaha Thanks a lot man! :-) All right, the stage is set...is the world ready for us? Well ready or not, here we come! Feel the storm...it's coming.

urlLink Hondata K Pro . This thing can read every possible sensor output the ECU receives (40 in total) and can program VTEC switch points, Cam advance/retard, Fuel and ignition for a vast set RPM intervals. It's a bit on the pricey end though... personally I'm really only interested in all the sensor readings and how the engine cope with the environment. I don't fancy screwing up my factory engine tuning.

urlLink Rogers PVR . Finally the long awaited Tivo service offered by Rogers. Rogers is getting extremely smart these days, maybe it's a good idea to invest in them so when they finally take over the holy grail of wired communications - combined video, voice and data, they will be unbeatable. Bell has some serious catch up to do.
